name: Trigger Point Therapy
summary: A manual therapy technique focused on identifying and releasing myofascial trigger points—tight, hypersensitive spots in muscle tissue that can cause localized or referred pain.
description: Trigger Point Therapy is a hands-on manual technique aimed at relieving pain and dysfunction caused by myofascial trigger points—taut bands of skeletal muscle fibers that are tender to touch and can refer pain to distant body regions. Practitioners apply sustained pressure, ischemic compression, massage, or needling techniques to deactivate trigger points, restore muscle length, and improve mobility. The therapy is often used for chronic musculoskeletal pain, tension headaches, fibromyalgia, and sports-related injuries. It can be performed by massage therapists, physical therapists, chiropractors, or physicians, and may be combined with stretching, exercise, or dry needling. Evidence suggests effectiveness for localized muscle pain, though high-quality research is mixed.

delivery_methods: Massage strokes to release taut bands
metadata.invasiveness_level: Minimally invasive (non-invasive for manual; invasive if dry needling used)
treatment_duration: Chronic pain: weekly sessions over 4–8 weeks, with maintenance as needed
metadata.training_required: Massage therapist, physical therapist, chiropractor, or physician training; dry needling requires specialized certification
metadata.regulatory_status: Manual therapy widely practiced; dry needling regulated differently by jurisdiction

contraindications: Absolute: acute injury with inflammation, open wounds, infection at site
Relative: bleeding disorders or anticoagulation, pregnancy (caution with abdominal/lumbar trigger points)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe with trained practitioners; mild soreness and bruising are common. Dry needling carries risks of bleeding, infection, or pneumothorax if poorly applied.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate – supportive evidence for pain reduction and muscle relaxation, though systematic reviews note methodological limitations.

items: Chronic neck, shoulder, and back pain

sections.text: Trigger point therapy works by applying pressure to taut, hyperirritable muscle fibers, disrupting the contracted sarcomere activity and restoring blood flow. Physiologically, this reduces nociceptive input, normalizes muscle spindle activity, and releases metabolic byproducts. Relief may also involve activation of descending inhibitory pain pathways and relaxation of myofascial tension.

sections.preparation: Assessment of pain patterns, palpation to locate trigger points, patient informed consent.
procedure: Palpate for taut bands and hypersensitive spots in muscles.
Apply sustained manual pressure (ischemic compression) until tissue softens.
Integrate stretching, massage, or movement to restore muscle length.
Reassess symptoms and pain referral patterns.
sections.frequency: Weekly sessions for chronic pain; as-needed for acute cases.
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies; chronic pain may require 6–12 sessions, with maintenance as needed.

immediate: Relief of localized pain, muscle relaxation
long_term: Better posture, reduced recurrence of pain, enhanced function

absolute: Acute injury or infection at site
special_considerations: Careful technique is required to avoid excessive discomfort.
Dry needling should only be performed by licensed professionals.

screening_required: Medical history for bleeding disorders or anticoagulant use

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies by frequency; often part of broader rehabilitation plan
sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered if performed by licensed physical therapist or chiropractor

items: Trigger points are common sources of referred musculoskeletal pain.
Manual release is often combined with stretching and corrective exercise.
Evidence supports benefit for pain relief but highlights need for more rigorous studies.
Dry needling is effective but regulated and requires advanced training.
